PRINCE ALBERT, The Great Commercial and Railway Centre in the North West.

PRINCE ALBERT, the trade centre of the Great North West, is situated on the south bank of the North Saskatchewan River, about thirty miles above its junction with the south branch of that great stream. With the last three years the peninsula thus formed has been more or less thickly settled for a hundred miles from its point, and now comprises a population of about 6,000 souls, exclusive of Indians.

Originally a Mission establishment of the Presbyterian Church, and the germ of the Settlement, Prince Albert proper, has grown into a busy, well-defined and substantially built town of about 2,000 inhabitants. A marked feature of the place is its entire freedom from the well understood "Far West" characteristics of frontier towns generally; everything is well-governed and orderly.

Imaginary buildings on maps have no place here, and neither are the principal buildings made of canvas. The leading structures are of brick, stone and wood, and the permanent features of Eastern Towns forcibly suggested. Our places of business, including mills, etc., will not suffer by comparison with those of Western Ontario. The different branches of trade correspond with any respectable town of the West, and may be particularized as follows:

Two large steam grist mills, with a grinding capacity of 35,000 lbs per day, two steam sawmills, shingle mills with a cutting capacity of 10,000 feet of lumber per day, one large steam planing mill and sash and door factory; thirteen general stores, wholesale and retail; two furniture stores, two boot and shoe stores, eight boarding houses; two tailoring establishments; two millinery and dress making establishments; one harness shop; three hardware stores; two banking houses; two jewellers' shops; one drug shop; two bakeries; three livery stables, etc.; which together did business last year to the amount of three-fourths of a million of dollars. Building material can be had cheaply, the best quality of brick is made at the town, and lime stone is abundant near by.

The Church of England has several missions throughout the Settlement, and a Church College and School at the west end of the town, all governed and regulated by a resident Bishop. The Presbyterians also have a fine church and school and several missions in the outlying districts, and the Methodist and Roman Catholic Churches are well represented.

Prince Albert has always been regarded as the wheat raising belt of the North West. From Lake of the Woods northwesterly it is about half way to the Rocky Mountains, and is also midway up the great Saskatchewan and finally it is on the ever green fringe of timber which marks the boundaries between the great fertile plains of the east and south and west, and the unbroken forest which stretches over hundreds of miles to the northern limit of the Pine. The old time difficulties in the way of reaching Prince Albert are quickly disappearing, a line of fast passenger steamers make weekly trips to Carlton, Banfffield and Edmonton on the West, and Grand Rapids, Selkirk and Winnipeg on the east side of the line. By stage coach from Prince Albert to Winnipeg is easy and also a two days. And meanwhile this is the objective point of the Portage, Westhampton and Northwestern Railway which is under agreement to give us train connection with the main line within eighteen months. The South Saskatchewan Valley Railway also is to begin at once by starting 500 men to work here and double as many more at Qu'Appelle. This road is only 200 miles from Prince Albert, and the Canadian Pacific at Fort Macleod will thus be pushed rapidly forward from both ends, and its early completion insured.

The soil found about Prince Albert is common to a vast country whose limits are not fixed, and is known as a rich sandy loam splendidly adapted to the raising of wheat and other cereals grown in the Western States, and it is safe to say that as far as the eye can see, the soil is excellent and the satisfaction in quality, the acreage placed under cultivation is well nigh doubled each succeeding year.

So many natural advantages uniting as they do at Prince Albert, experience has shown, unmistakably have but one result: a Chicago, a Minneapolis, a Winnipeg; and as the relative distance is maintained, our great city of the near future on the banks of the Saskatchewan.

Practically we are at the foot of a great river, a direct descent of country equal in net greatness that drained by the Mississippi, at the northwestern limit of the plains and at the lower edge of an immeasurable forest reaching to the Arctic Ocean.

Already the growth of the Settlement is wonderful, and thus early in its history one receives the comfort blessings and security of the Eastern homes left behind. As we are 500 miles from Winnipeg, the business done there is ours. There is a growing demand from the farther West for supplies of all kinds and if the future may be judged by the past, Prince Albert will be to the Great Peace River Valley in process of settlement what Winnipeg was still is to the valley of the Saskatchewan, the base of supplies.

Railway connection with the steamer of the Saskatchewan at this point will make it the distributing centre of a country half the size of Europe, and when the Hudson's Bay Company takes across the Atlantic is an accomplished fact, who can say what possibilities may not be opened up?

Capitalists, Farmers, Mechanics and men generally whose minds are practical cannot fail to readily understand that the advantages offered herein have stood alone unequalled in the world.

A few of the natural causes which operate to make Prince Albert and surrounding country a desirable field for agriculturists and capitalists will be mentioned in order of their importance:

Situated on the banks of a mighty river draining a country greater in extent than that drained by the Mississippi, and navigable through a thousand miles of its most important supply of wood and coal, and the boundless and fertile prairie stretching away to the east, south and west, awaiting but the advent of the husbandman to cause it to yield its fields of golden grain. The past growth and present prosperity of the town, notwithstanding the adverse influences with which its citizens have had to contend augurs well for its future advancement, and we may safely prophesy that it will continue to advance with giant strides until it takes its place as one of the great cities of the West.

QUEEN'S BIRTHDAY

Celebration in the North West

Thursday last being the sixty-fifth anniversary of Her Majesty's birthday, the residents of Prince Albert and the adjoining country turned out in large numbers for the purpose of celebrating the event as well as for the usual meet and race day. Nearly all the places of business were closed for the day, and anyone who could not get away took advantage of the opportunity to see the best of their ability. A committee had been appointed to form a programme of events, but the committee was unable to do so by 10 a.m., thus the programme had everything in readiness and a start was made. The first item on the programme was:

STANDING JUMP.

For this contest there were many entries, and several good jumps were made. Wright took first place with 10ft. 2in.; A. Hudson, 2nd; 10ft. 3in.; H. Porter, 3rd; 9ft. 6in.

THREE STANDING JUMPS.

For this there were four competitors entered, D. McLeod taking first prize with 11ft.; H. D. Peterson, 2nd, with 10ft. 8in.; N. McLeod, 3rd; and J. Smith, 4th.

NINE STANDING JUMPS.

Nine competitors entered for this contest was very keen. D. Peterson, 1st; 2nd; 10ft. 5in.; James Mac, 2nd; 10ft. 3in.

RUNNING RACE.

There were two entries for this, D. Peterson winning and easily clearing 10ft.; A. Hudson, 2nd; 9ft. 11in.

FIFTY-YARD RACE.

This was the longest affair of the day. Two entries, H. D. Peterson, 1st; 2nd; 8ft. 6in.; N. McLeod, 2nd; 7ft. 10in.

VARIED WITH POLE.

Three entries were made for this contest, which was considered as good as we would wish to have seen it. A. Hudson, 1st; 7ft. 10in.; A. Morrison, 2nd; 7ft. 11in.

HUNDRED-YARD RACE.

Four competitors took part in this race, which had been looked forward to with much interest, owing to the well known swiftness of some of the contestants. This was the only race of the day that was won by a horse having a foot start being claimed, but not allowed. The first place was awarded to D. Peterson, 1st; 10ft. 11in.

THREE-LEGGED RACE.

This was a very amusing race, and was won by H. D. Peterson, 1st; Kay Linklater and Nelson coming in second.

Two hundred yards race.

For this race there were three entries. The first place was taken easily by S. McLeod; A. Morrison, 2nd; 10ft. 11in.

There was not much excitement over this race, it being a straightaway track and not so easy viewing as the others. The first place was taken by McKay, and the second by Linklater.

SMOKING RACE.

The third race of the afternoon, the contestants in this race experienced considerable difficulty in getting up smoke, but after considerable smoking, smoke credits were getting away pretty well together, J. Linklater securing first prize.

LOCAL AND GENERAL NEWS.

Paragliders printed at the Times office. J. C. MacKenzie has received a large order of boots and shoes this week, and he is determined to dispose of all his stock.

If you want a saving, make your purchases on the installment plan, monthly or quarterly payments, without interest, at MacKenzie's Office.

Tenders are invited for the erection of a brick house for the Presbyterian church. The building is to be completed and ready for occupation by September next.

The steamer Northcote, Capt. Wabber, took on board Mrs. MacKenzie, etc., here, which she will distribute at various points along the river. She goes up as far as Fort MacKenzie.

Judging from the number of steamboat boats that have landed there during the past week, we would be led to believe that not only a landing but a town has been established in the vicinity of Mr. Kay's mill.

Stewart's Western Transportation Company have purchased a large consignment of goods of all descriptions by boat from Cumberland, where it had been stored during the winter, which they propose to sell at a low figure.

We have received the first number of the Gladstone Age. It is a very well got up and printed paper, twenty-eight columns, quite a large vessel for its size about. We hope the proprietors, Modde Bros., may succeed.

The regular number of the Moose Jaw News has come to hand. It is a neat little six-page paper, well printed and neatly bound. We give credit to both the town and its enterprising proprietors. We wish it all prosperity.

The Hon. Lawrence Clarke informs us that the Presbyterians of Prince Albert decided not to make any charges for goods sold in Cumberland last winter. Various reasons were given why these charges can have been refunded, such as the willingness of the H. R. Co.

The Hon. Lawrence Clarke left town by boat on Saturday morning for Edmonton, Fort Pitt and other points. The hon. gentleman has been obliged to attend to personal business before the election, and to vote for MacKenzie, even if he has to charter a steamboat at his own expense.

Rev. J. Sweright has been authorized by the Presbytery of Manitoba to erect Prince Albert Church. He will be joined by members from a congregation. This will be the first Presbyterian congregation in the Territorial District. Voting papers have been issued to the voters for the purpose of electing two elders.

Mr. VanLaren, machinist and mechanic, has recently received a large order of goods from a lumber yard. He has been engaged in buying lumber for his boat last day and week, and before evening has disposed of them all. Last Monday he received a large number of orders for sawing machines, with the hope of preparing to sell a few this fall.

Charles Thompson, general blacksmith, etc., has received by boat a splendid assortment of bent runners, and shafts for wagons, plows, buggies, wagons, sleds, lorgnoses, and various other articles of the kind, so that last material, which we are sure will be greatly prized by farmers and others in this country. Mr. Thompson deserves a call.

Bill Books neatly and promptly printed at this office.

The following items of the last meeting of the Foreign Mission Committee of the Presbyterian Church may be of interest to our readers. The minutes of the meeting were read and the proposed establishment of a College in Prince Albert. The district committee of the Western Division were officially notified that the committee cannot see its way to recommend to the regional Assembly the raising of half the property required.

Com. J. H. Davis, Superintendent of the Winnipeg & Western Transportation Co., came to Prince Albert today. The gentleman informs us that he is the first connection of the company this season to run a steamer from Prince Albert to Grand Rapids via Prince Albert, and will go on to Edmonton, making close connection with the steamer from Winnipeg to Grand Rapids. This will be a great convenience to the traveling public during the season of navigation and will do much to take away the complaints and others. The Commissioner left Prince Albert by steamer North West for below on Saturday afternoon, expecting to return here about the last July.
